result.markdown:
# Table Formatting {#sec-tables} Flextable is a great package for formatting tables. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(flextable) ``` ::: ## Data First, let's get some data. I've included a subset of data for the first nine pokemon from Dave Parr's pokedex package. We have some character and numeric columns, plus some missing data (not all pokemon have a secondary type). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # devtools::install_github("DaveParr/pokedex") # data from pokedex::pokemon pokemon <- data.frame( id = 1:9, name = c("Bulbasaur", "Ivysaur", "Venusaur", "Charmander", "Charmeleon", "Charizard", "Squirtle", "Wartortle", "Blastoise"), height = c(0.7, 1, 2, 0.6, 1.1, 1.7, 0.5, 1, 1.6), weight = c(6.9, 13, 100, 8.5, 19, 90.5, 9, 22.5, 85.5), type_1 = c("grass", "grass", "grass", "fire", "fire", "fire", "water", "water", "water"), type_2 = c("poison", "poison", "poison", NA, NA, "flying", NA, NA, NA) ) ``` ::: ## Basic table Look at how the table displays by default. This will display in one way in RStudio, but a different way when you render the document, so also render it and look at the HTML version. ::: {#tbl-basic .cell tbl-cap='A default table display'} ```{.r .cell-code} pokemon ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
| id|name | height| weight|type_1 |type_2 | |--:|:----------|------:|------:|:------|:------| | 1|Bulbasaur | 0.7| 6.9|grass |poison | | 2|Ivysaur | 1.0| 13.0|grass |poison | | 3|Venusaur | 2.0| 100.0|grass |poison | | 4|Charmander | 0.6| 8.5|fire |NA | | 5|Charmeleon | 1.1| 19.0|fire |NA | | 6|Charizard | 1.7| 90.5|fire |flying | | 7|Squirtle | 0.5| 9.0|water |NA | | 8|Wartortle | 1.0| 22.5|water |NA | | 9|Blastoise | 1.6| 85.5|water |NA |
::: ::: Now see how it looks if you use `flextable()`. ::: {#tbl-flextable .cell tbl-cap='A basic flextable'} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

id

name

height

weight

type_1

type_2

1

Bulbasaur

0.7

6.9

grass

poison

2

Ivysaur

1.0

13.0

grass

poison

3

Venusaur

2.0

100.0

grass

poison

4

Charmander

0.6

8.5

fire

5

Charmeleon

1.1

19.0

fire

6

Charizard

1.7

90.5

fire

flying

7

Squirtle

0.5

9.0

water

8

Wartortle

1.0

22.5

water

9

Blastoise

1.6

85.5

water

``` ::: ::: ## Cusomising tables ### Subset/reorder columns You can use the `col_keys` argument to select a subset of columns, or change their order. You can also do this with data wrangling before you send a data frame to flextable, but this can be easier in some instances. ::: {#tbl-col_keys .cell tbl-cap='Subsetting columns with `col_keys`'} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon, col_keys = c("name", "weight", "height")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

name

weight

height

Bulbasaur

6.9

0.7

Ivysaur

13.0

1.0

Venusaur

100.0

2.0

Charmander

8.5

0.6

Charmeleon

19.0

1.1

Charizard

90.5

1.7

Squirtle

9.0

0.5

Wartortle

22.5

1.0

Blastoise

85.5

1.6

``` ::: ::: ### Header Use `set_header_labels()` to customise the header. You can change the name of one or more column. ::: {#tbl-set_header_labels .cell tbl-cap='Customising the header with `set_header_labels()`'} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon) |> set_header_labels(id = "ID", name = "Name", height = "Height (m)", weight = "Weight (kg)", type_1 = "Type 1", type_2 = "Type 2") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

ID

Name

Height (m)

Weight (kg)

Type 1

Type 2

1

Bulbasaur

0.7

6.9

grass

poison

2

Ivysaur

1.0

13.0

grass

poison

3

Venusaur

2.0

100.0

grass

poison

4

Charmander

0.6

8.5

fire

5

Charmeleon

1.1

19.0

fire

6

Charizard

1.7

90.5

fire

flying

7

Squirtle

0.5

9.0

water

8

Wartortle

1.0

22.5

water

9

Blastoise

1.6

85.5

water

``` ::: ::: If you have headers that have a nested structure, and their names reflect this (like "category_instance1" and "category_instance2"), you can use `separate_header()` to separate them. ::: {#tbl-separate_header .cell tbl-cap='Nesting the header with `separate_header()`'} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon) |> separate_header() |> set_header_labels(type_1 = "primary", type_2 = "secondary") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

id

name

height

weight

type

primary

secondary

1

Bulbasaur

0.7

6.9

grass

poison

2

Ivysaur

1.0

13.0

grass

poison

3

Venusaur

grass

poison

Charmander

0.6

8.5

fire

5

Charmeleon

1.1

19.0

fire

6

Charizard

1.7

90.5

fire

flying

Squirtle

water

8

Wartortle

1.0

22.5

water

9

Blastoise

1.6

85.5

water

``` ::: ::: Alternatively, you can manually add extra header rows. ::: {#tbl-add_header_row .cell tbl-cap='Manually add a header row with `add_header_row()`'} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon) |> add_header_row(values = c("", "Measurements", "Types"), colwidths = c(2, 2, 2)) |> set_header_labels(type_1 = "primary", type_2 = "secondary") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Measurements

Types

id

name

primary

``` ::: ::: ### Alignment The defaults are usually correct, left-aligning text and right-aligning numbers, but you can also customise this using the `align()` function. The code below centre aligns the first row of the header to "center", and then right aligns the body cells in the "name" column. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon) |> add_header_row(values = c("", "Measurements", "Types"), colwidths = c(2, 2, 2)) |> set_header_labels(type_1 = "primary", type_2 = "secondary") |> align(align = "center", i = 1, part = "header") |> align(align = "right", j = "name", part = "body") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Measurements

Types

id

name

height

weight

primary

secondary

1

Bulbasaur

6.9

grass

water

``` ::: ::: :::{.callout-note} See if you can figure out what `i` and `j` mean, using trial-and-error first, and the help function if you get stuck. ::: ## Themes There are some built-in themes you can use. ### Alafoli ::: {#tbl-alafoli .cell tbl-cap='The alafoli theme'} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon) |> theme_alafoli() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Defaults You can set a ton of defaults using `set_flextable_defaults()`. Do this at the top of your script and all of the tables in your document will have consistent styles. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} set_flextable_defaults(digits = 2, font.size = 16, theme_fun = theme_apa, na_str = "(none)") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} flextable(pokemon) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

id

name

height

weight

type_1

type_2

1

Bulbasaur

6.90

(none)

``` ::: ::: ## Next Steps You can learn a lot more about how to customisie tables from the [flextable book](https://ardata-fr.github.io/flextable-book/). 1. As a group, make a list of things you might want to do to tables, like highlight a row, add footnotes, include images, or set border styles. 2. Divide up the list and each create a short tutorial for how to accomplish the thing, using just the `pokemon` table. 3. Share your tutorial with the group!
